titlestmt.titleproper: Register to the Papers of Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Adrienne Scholtz

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 00:00

did.unittitle: The Papers of Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz.

langmaterial.language: Materials chiefly in English and Russian.

did.abstract: Correspondence and other papers, photographs, and additional materials by and about the Russian-American pianist Vladimir Horowitz (1903-1989) and his wife Wanda Toscanini Horowitz (1907-1998)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to qualified researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment. Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Papers of Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz are the generous gift of Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz. The collection was presented to the Music Library in twelve installments from 1986 to 1992.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Papers of Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 55, The Papers of Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 9 series as follows: I. Correspondence. II. Programs and Program Notes. III. Photographs. IV. Clippings. V. Scrapbooks. VI. Contracts, Royalty and Box Office Statements, Expenses. VII. Items from the Library of Vladimir Horowitz. VIII. Awards. IX. Miscellaneous Items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Papers of Vladimir Horowitz and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz (1784-1991) reflect the life and work of the legendary pianist, Vladimir Horowitz, and of his wife, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz. The Papers chronicle Horowitz's life and illustrious seventy-one year career from Kiev to New York.

The Papers include correspondence, programs, photographs, clippings, scrapbooks, contracts, royalty statements, awards, certificates, jewelry, and a wide range of memorabilia. Included too are manuscript and published music, autograph letters of famous composers, and original works of art from the Horowitzes' private collection. The Papers document the Horowitzes' close association with such figures as Sergei Rachmaninoff, Rudolf Serkin, Arthur Rubinstein, Nathan Milstein, Gregor Piatigorsky, Olin Downes, Isaac Stern, Arturo Toscanini, and Bruno Walter. The music includes holograph manuscripts of works by Horowitz, Poulenc, and Prokofiev. There is also much published music with markings by Horowitz and/or inscriptions from composers and friends.

Very important are the 218 unpublished live recordings on acetate disc of Horowitz's Carnegie Hall recitals of the 1940s and 50s. Horowitz had these 12 and 16 inch discs made for personal use. They are cataloged and housed at Yale University's Historical Sound Recordings Collection, where they have been copied unto tape for preservation purposes and are available for researchers. Mrs. Horowitz also donated a treasure of items pertaining to her father, Arturo Toscanini. These include many photographs, scrapbooks, correspondence, and memorabilia. There are also 324 recordings by Toscanini or Toscanini and Horowitz made by the Franklin Mint Society, Musica Amica, RCA Artistique, RCA Camden, RCA Victor/Red Seal, RCA Victrola, RCA Victrola (Italy), RCA Victor-Japan, and Columbia. These are also housed and cataloged at Yale University's Historical Sound Recordings Collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vladimir Horowitz (in Russian, Gorowitz) was born in Berdichev, near Kiev, on October 1, 1903. His father, Simeon, was an electrical engineer, and his mother, Sophie , a pianist. It was Sophie who gave Volodya (as he was affectionately called), his sister, Regina, and brothers Jacob and George, their first music lessons. When he was ten years old, Horowitz entered the Kiev Conservatory where he studied with Vladimir Puchalsky, Sergei Tarnowsky, and Felix Blumenfeld.

At first, Horowitz aspired to be a composer, and as a teenager produced several compositions (the holograph manuscript of one of these works, Etude-fantasie es-dur op. 4 : Les Vagues (dedicated to Tarnovsky), is among the Papers). But revolution and the hardships of life under the Bolsheviks intervened, forcing him to abandon his dream of becoming a composer (his dazzling piano transcriptions written later in his career attest to his compositional talents). With his father's successful business and most of their possessions, including the piano, seized by the Bolsheviks, and the Horowitzes living together with all of their relatives in poverty, Vladimir Horowitz was determined to use his phenomenal talent as a pianist to help his family. He graduated from the Conservatory in 1920, giving his first public performance in Kiev on May 30 of that year. His paternal uncle Alexander, a pupil of Scriabin, became his first manager. In 1922, Uncle Alexander was replaced as manager by the state, which then dictated the careers of Horowitz, his sister, and his good friend Nathan Milstein. From 1922 to 1925 he performed extensively in Kharkov, Kiev, Moscow, and Leningrad, and his reputation as a virtuoso grew.

After state management, Horowitz's career was overseen by Alexander Merovitch, who helped Horowitz leave Russia in 1925. The decision to leave was difficult, and the only family member he was to ever see again was his father, once, in 1934. His first performance outside of Russia was in Berlin, on January 2, 1926. From 1926 to 1927 he gave sixty-nine concerts throughout Europe, and became immensely popular with the public. He studied briefly with Alfred Cortot in Paris, in 1928. Horowitz switched management to Arthur Judson, and on January 12, 1928, made his American debut with Sir Thomas Beecham and the New York Philharmonic playing Tchaikovsky's First Piano Concerto. His debut was sensational; the audience was amazed by his performance. Horowitz's career took off: he performed for sold-out concerts, commanded the highest fees, and became universally celebrated. In 1933 Mr. Horowitz performed Beethoven's Emperor Concerto with Toscanini and the New York Philharmonic as part of a Beethoven cycle. The concert was a great success, and he won the admiration of Toscanini, whose daughter, Wanda, he married on December 21, 1933, in Milan. Their daughter, Sonia, was born in 1934.

The Horowitzes came to the United States in 1939, and he became a citizen in 1942. He gave the world premiere of Samuel Barber's Piano Sonata on December 9, 1949, in Havana. Horowitz began a twelve-year retirement from concert life after his Silver Jubilee concert on February 25, 1953, during which time he made a few recordings. Horowitz made his triumphant return to the concert stage at Carnegie Hall on May 9, 1965. Throngs of eager fans stood in the ticket line overnight, and the tickets were sold out in two hours.

Horowitz's televised recital in September 1968 was a huge success, allowing viewers across the country to see him in performance. After a retirement from 1969 to 1974, during which Horowitz made and reissued recordings, he gave the first piano recital at the new Metropolitan Opera House on November 17, 1974. On January 8, 1978, he celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of his American debut at Carnegie Hall playing Rachmaninoff's Concerto No. 3 with Eugene Ormandy and the New York Philharmonic. He performed in Europe for the first time in thirty-one years in a recital in London's Royal Festival Hall on May 22, 1982, and he played a series of recitals for the first time in Japan in 1983. In the following years he toured Europe and Japan, performed in the United States, and made recordings, videos, telecasts, and films. Horowitz made an historic return to the Soviet Union after a sixty-one year absence in 1986, and for this was later awarded the United States Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Reagan.
Horowitz performed at the White House for Presidents Hoover, Carter, and Reagan. President Bush bestowed upon him the National Medal of Arts in 1989.

On November 1, 1989, Horowitz made what was to be The Last Recording. He died suddenly, on November 5, 1989, of a heart attack. After the funeral in New York, his body was flown to Milan where he was buried in the Toscanini family plot.

controlaccess.title: Vladimir and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is divided into two subseries: A. Personal; and B. By Subject. The personal correspondence is arranged alphabetically by sender then chronologically. Copies and drafts of letters from Horowitz are filed with the recipient's correspondence and a note has been made in the register. Replies made in behalf of Horowitz by others such as Harold Shaw, Peter Gelb, and secretaries, are filed under Horowitz. This series includes correspondence to and from Vladimir Horowitz and Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, as well as from Sonia Horowitz, and to and from Arturo Toscanini. Original correspondence from Vladimir Horowitz to Wanda Toscanini Horowitz and Arturo Toscanini, and from Sonia Horowitz to Arturo Toscanini are listed under the authors' names. The correspondence in the second subseries is grouped by subject and listed chronologically with a chronological arrangement within each group. Fan mail is included in this subseries.

Originals of letters from important people which were found grouped by subject are now filed with personal correspondence and photocopies of these remain in subseries B, VI. CONTRACTS, and IX. MISCELLANEOUS ITEMS - Items pertaining to Toscanini.
Enclosures are noted and counted in the items column.

Cross-references have been made between individuals with correspondence in both subseries as well as between series. For instance, cross-references have been made between correspondence in series VI. CONTRACTS... and I.A. Personal Correspondence. There are also cross-references from various forms of names to the main entries.

The entries under Arturo Toscanini, in I.A., include correspondence to and from Toscanini. The correspondence from Toscanini to his family is followed by correspondence to others, which includes photocopies of correspondence from other important people (the originals are at the New York Public Library).
A pencil note appears on the item or its folder for correspondence originally found in another series such as V. SCRAPBOOKS (which have been microfilmed and disassembled).
Drafts of letters on legal paper and paper in poor condition have been copied onto acid-free paper.
There is one oversize box (132) for correspondence which is housed at the end with other oversize boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into three subseries: A. Programs; B. Lists of Programs; and C. Analytical Notes. The bulk of the programs are for performances by Horowitz, with some programs by others at the end. Subseries A is listed chronologically. Subseries B includes various lists of Horowitz's performances arranged alphabetically by city or chronologically. Subseries C includes analytical program and liner notes arranged chronologically.
A pencil note has been made on programs which were originally in the scrapbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs are divided into five subseries: A. Vladimir Horowitz, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, Sonia Horowitz, and Others; B. Others; C. Concert Halls, Ticket Lines, Places, and Objects; D. Toscanini Photographs; and E. Photo Albums. Subseries A is arranged chronologically, subseries B is arranged alphabetically, and subseries C, D, and E, are arranged chronologically.
Negatives are noted and included in the item count. Prints were made and added to the Papers for the slides and negatives which were originally without prints.
Dates, names, and other information is supplied, when possible, in brackets on the back of each photograph and or on the acid-free envelope or wrapper.
The photographs in the albums in subseries E have been removed for preservation purposes, photographed, and the negatives are laid in.

Oversize photographs are housed in an oversize box (133) at the end with other oversize boxes. The exceptions to this are the oversize photographs which are too large for a box. One photograph is housed in an oversize folder (ovf), and one framed photograph is stored separately in the Music Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The clippings are arranged chronologically with the exception of several subject groups which appear in the chronological list filed under the date of the earliest article. The clippings have been copied onto acid-free paper, and the originals discarded. Clippings which were already photocopied were not recopied onto acid-free paper.

odd.head: General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are a total of 29 scrapbooks containing clippings, photographs, correspondence (including many telegrams), programs, advertisements, and miscellaneous items. Twenty-six have been microfilmed and an acid-free copyflo has been made from the microfilms. There are 5 reels of microfilm. Numbers have been assigned (by Yale University Music Library for filming) to each scrapbook, which are arranged in chronological order. The box, reel, and frame numbers, and the inclusive dates are listed for the copyflo of each scrapbook.
An additional 3 scrapbooks have been photocopied onto acid-free paper and microfilmed. The microfilm is laid in.

The original scrapbooks have been disassembled and the original correspondence, photographs, programs, advertisements, and miscellaneous items filed in their corresponding series. Cross-references have been made to the scrapbooks, and there are pencil notes on the items or their acid-free wrappers. The original clippings were discarded for preservation purposes. The clippings in part duplicate those in IV. CLIPPINGS.

There is another microfilm containing several copies of 9 clippings. This microfilm came with the Papers and no copyflo has been made since it is not a scrapbook and the articles are all in IV. CLIPPINGS.

CONTRACTS, ROYALTY AND BOX OFFICE STATEMENTS, AND EXPENSES

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into three subseries: A. Concerts; B. Recordings; and C. Bills, Receipts, and Expenses. The first subseries is further divided into: 1. Contracts, box office statements, etc. (arranged chronologically by concert date with all items pertaining to a concert together); 2. Management contracts, legal actions, and pay stubs (arranged by subject, then chronologically); and 3. Route books, schedules, and concert information (arranged either chronologically or by concert hall within each subject group). Subseries B and C are arranged chronologically within each subject group.

Some correspondence from important persons who are listed in I.A. CORRESPONDENCE - Personal, has been copied and the originals filed with I.A, the copies remaining with the contracts. Notes appear on the items or their folders when this has been done and cross- references have been made in the register. Fan mail included with the contracts has not been copied and remains with the contracts. A cross-reference appears in the register from I.B. CORRESPONDENCE - Subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contracts, box office statements, scalings, seating plans, duplicate programs, press releases, visa applications, itineraries, pay stubs, and housing arrangements. Includes cancellations and postponements (postponed concerts are filed under the later date)

ITEMS FROM THE LIBRARY OF VLADIMIR HOROWITZ

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into three subseries: A. Music - Manuscript and Printed Music Given to the Yale University Music Library 22 March 1991 and Earlier; B. Manuscript Music Given to the Yale University Music Library 17 December 1991; and C. Manuscript Music and Correspondence Given to the Yale University Music Library 17 December 1991.

Subseries A is an alphabetical list by composer which includes the items kept by the Yale University Music Library. Rare items have been cataloged separately, and may be accessed by Yale University Music Library's online catalog. The remaining items are those with markings and or inscriptions, as well as those with heavy usage or some significance. These items have box and folder numbers at the end of each entry. A card file of the library which came with the Papers is housed in boxes 103 to 105. Notes with further information, notes for items not found, and cards for items found without cards have been added to this file.
Four loose-leaf notebooks containing photocopies of published music, repertoire for recitals, are listed and housed at the end of the alphabetical list by composer.
Subseries B is a list of holograph music which are enclosures in correspondence. They are housed with I. CORRESPONDENCE and listed here with cross-references.
Subseries C is an alphabetical listing of holograph correspondence by composer. These items have been transferred to Misc. Ms. 372, Miscellaneous Letters and Documents File.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The awards are listed alphabetically by issuing organization, then chronologically. They include certificates, plaques, medals, statuettes, paperweights, ice buckets, trophies, a book, a vase, and a SONY Walkman. The oversize awards are housed in oversize boxes at the end (142-151, 160) with the exception of 2 awards which are too large for the oversize boxes. These 2 awards are housed separately in the Yale University Music Library (designated ov in the register). Correspondence accompanying the awards has been copied and the originals (with cross-references) filed with I.A. CORRESPONDENCE - Personal. The copies remain with the awards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are two subseries: A. Items Pertaining to Vladimir Horowitz, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, and Sonia Horowitz; and B. Items Pertaining to Arturo Toscanini. The first subseries includes announcements and invitations, items pertaining to Vladimir Horowitz's death, certificates, radio scripts, articles and interviews by or with Vladimir Horowitz, photographs and prints of items from the Horowitzes' private art collection, press books, publicity announcements, and other biographical material, travel items, books and pamphlets, portraits and caricatures of or having to do with Vladimir Horowitz, ticket stubs, advertisements, calendars, and portraits of others. There are also many other miscellaneous items which include jewelry, wallets, clothing, printing blocks, and memorabilia. Subseries B. - Items pertaining to Arturo Toscanini, includes items pertaining to Arturo Toscanini's death, discographies, anniversary celebration material, items pertaining to the Arturo Toscanini commemorative postage stamps and first-day-of-issue envelopes, and memorabilia.

The items are grouped by subject and then listed either chronologically or alphabetically by author, as in the case with books and pamphlets. Cross-references appear between this series and other series in the register.

The oversize items are housed in oversize boxes at the end (152-163), with the exception of 4 oversize items which do not fit in boxes. One item is housed in an oversize folder (designated ovf in the register). The 3 others are housed separately in the Yale University Music Library (designated ov in the register).
Originals of the correspondence in this series are filed with I.A. CORRESPONDENCE - Personal, and photocopies remain with the miscellaneous items.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Gift by Metcalf to his friend, the actor, David Warfield around 1906. It was later auctioned off by Parke Bernet from the estate of David Warfield in 1951, Sale No. 1291 where it was cataloged by the title, First Green, which caused confusion over its identity. In 1972, Sotheby Parke Bernet Sale No. 3373 sold this painting under the title, Landscape. It was purchased by Wildenstein & Co. In 1973, Vladimir Horowitz purchased it from the Wildenstein Gallery

odd.head: General
odd.p: Oval bas-relief ivory carving, 1 5/8 x 2 1/4", within a rectangular dark brown walnut frame (lacquered) 3 1/2 x 2 7/8", on the verso of which is its handwritten provenance (see below), preserved in a later red morocco gilt-stamped Santos de Cartier jewelry box 4 11/16 x 4 1/6", light scratches to the frame with small losses of the lacquered surface in two places, a white glue appearing substance has leaked out from behind the carving.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Provenance: gift of Daniele, the daughter of Hans von Bülow (1830-1894) and Cosima (Liszt's daughter) to Franz Liszt, who, tradition holds, kept it on his night-stand, subsequently giving it to Professor Wilhelm Guida. From Professor Guida the medallion passed to Friedelind Wagner (daughter of Richard Wagner's son, Siegfried). She gave it to Arturo Toscanini (he helped Friedelind immigrate to America), and Toscanini gave the carving to his son- in-law, Vladimir Horowitz, who kept it on his night-stand like his great hero, Franz Liszt [by Kenneth Nesheim]
